photos.description: O.H. Culver (age 44) in his Friday Harbor newspaper office. Otis and brother Fred were journalists and founded this paper and operated it for several years.
The parlor of the Alderbrook Farmhouse.
photos.notes: The painting on the right was painted by Diana (Aikens) Culver. It now hangs in Ken and Marcia Culver's home in Bellingham, WA.

photos.description: TBD
George Nelson Culver overlooks Alderbrook Farm (David Hall).
Duplicate of 0265

photos.people: Dickie McDonald, Bruce Culver, Carolyn (Culver) Leonhardt
photos.description: Happily sitting on Carroll Culver's 1950 Ford Tractor. The MacDonald family stayed at Pt. Lawrence for many summers. Dickie (a city boy from Seattle) got to have lots of country experiences. He was a little naive' and had a few tricks played on him including going on a 'snipe' hunt which Ken and Bruce loved to inflict on unsuspecting kids of resort guests.

Cabins 5,6, and 7 to the left. The ground was still rough, which would later be turned into lawn. There was a small fruit tree planted in front of each cabin in the back row, protected by deer fences. In 1968 Cabin 5 was moved down the hill by placing round logs under it and using the old Ford Tractor. It was joined together with Cabin 1 to become the bones of the existing Culver Family cabin. (Ken)

Recent snowfall. The lodge was not insulated so heat from the big wood stove in the kitchen would melt the snow in a few hours on the left hand end of the Lodge where the Culver family lived. It would appear that the overhead walkway had not yet been connected to the stairway that would lead up to cabin 1 and to the parking lot.
Cabins 7,8,9, and 10 in the back row and cabin 4 in front. There were no bathrooms in any of the cabins. Carroll raised the price from $4.50 per night to around $7.00.
Holens always stayed in cabin 4. Elmer and Helmer - identical Norwegian twins. Elmer had a family with 2 kids, while Helmer was a bachelor and a real character.

photos.people: Ken Culver (14 months old), Margaret Johanson Fickel
photos.description: Judging from the paneling this would be in the Lodge Dining Room.

photos.people: Bruce Culver, Ken Culver, Carolyn Culver, Jean (Rothenhoefer) Culver
photos.description: Dressed warmly to go somewhere in the old Ford Pickup.

photos.people: Mary Hall, Mason Hall, Carroll Culver, Florian Johanson, Mark Fickel, Helge Johanson, Jim Fickel, Jane Fickel, Leda Hipkoe
photos.description: A family get together of 4 of the 5 O.H. Culver Children. Back row: Mary Hall, Mason Hall, Carroll Culver, Florian Johanson, Mark Fickel, Helge Johanson. Front row: Jim Fickel, Jane Fickel, Leda Hipkoe. (Ken)

photos.people: Julie Stiles, Karen Diefendorf, Marcia Culver, Margie Ostle, John Diefendorf
photos.description: From left: Julie Stiles, Karen Diefendorf, Marcia Culver, Margie Ostle, John Diefendorf at the water pump. The Farmhouse has no inside plumbing, instead it relied on this dug well or 'cistern'. The pump was cranky and generally required priming and waiting for the 'leathers' to swell up in the pump chamber before it would work.

Cabin 5 being moved into place next to Cabin 1. Ken had just been decommissioned from the Coast Guard in Alaska and Ken and Marcia decided to live on Orcas during that summer prior to returning to Seattle, where Marcia had a teaching job in the fall. The photo shows cabin 1 stripped to its studs. Ken and Marcia lived in cabin #2 next door that summer, and often slept outside on an old double spring and mattress from one of the cabins. During the move of cabin 5 down the slope the cabin started rolling faster than planned and one of the logs rolled over Marcia's sister Wendy Barnes' foot. Fortunately she was not seriously injured but I have never heard the last of it. (Ken)

Jacking, prying, rolling with log rollers and planks. I used the same system as Carroll had used for many years to launch and retrieve the floats on the beach. That's Carroll on his hands and knees helping out. (Ken)

Cabin #2 - Ken and Marcia's home for the summer while working on cabin 1. It was a particularly nice summer weatherwise, and we slept outside on this old double bed with steel spring and mattress much of the time. Parked to the left was our trusty Ford Econoline Van in which we had honeymooned to San Francisco and taken to Sitka, Alaska when Marcia taught school there to be near Ken, stationed on Biorka Island as Commanding Officer of the Loran Transmitting station.

The first version of cabin 1 and cabin 5 being joined together to make Ken and Marcia Culver's summer cabin. The cabin was sided with 1x12 Cedar boards and battens and remained on its original post and block foundation for many years after. The deck would be added soon after this photo was taken.

Ken hand splitting cedar shakes from shake 'bolts' using a hardwood mallet and 'fro'. The Cedar was all beach combed from local beaches, cut into lengths, and then into stacks of shake 'bolts'. The bolts were split into 'barn shakes'. This made for a shake that was the same thickness from top to bottom. Barn shakes are thinner than traditional shakes and dry out more quickly so they last longer. Traditional 'tapered' shakes required turning over the bolt each time, resulting in a taper. Hand split cedar shakes were the longest lasting because the surface of the shake followed the grain of the wood, creating minute channels to carry away the water. Sawed shakes tended to be much more uniform, but they absorbed water and often rotted much sooner. Between Marcia and I we split enough shakes that summer to cover both Cabin 1 and 5 which were now joined together. (Ken)
